questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the GFR?

choices.text: Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.solution:
A decrease in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

A decrease in Bowman's Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure increases GFR because it reduces the opposing force to filtration, thus enhancing the net filtration pressure and increasing the amount of filtrate formed.

Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:

  • Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf: This coefficient depends on the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries. 
  • Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Conditions with urinary tract obstruction can lead to an increase in this pressure and a fall in GFR.
  • Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure: Accumulation of plasma proteins that are not filtered from the blood contributes to this pressure, and an increase reduces further filtration and GFR. It is directly proportional to the following factors: Arterial plasma colloid osmotic pressure.
  • Filtration fraction : An increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.

Other options : 

Option A: Efferent Arteriole Dilation reduces the resistance to blood leaving the glomerulus. This leads to a decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. A reduction in hydrostatic pressure lowers the driving force for filtration, resulting in a decreased GFR.

Option B: Afferent Arteriole Constriction decreases blood flow into the glomerulus. This lowers the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. Lower pressure reduces the filtration rate across the glomerular capillary wall, leading to a decrease in GFR.

Option C: Increase in Glomerular Plasma Flow: If glomerular plasma flow increases but the efferent arteriole doesn't constrict, the extra blood flow is quickly carried away. This prevents a significant rise in the pressure inside the glomerular capillaries. As a result, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) doesn't significantly increase, because the necessary increase in filtration pressure doesn't occur.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting GFR

Determinants

Physiological/Pathophysiological Causes

↓Kf (filtration coefficient)→ ↓GFR

Renal disease, diabetes mellitus, hypertension

↑PB → ↓GFR

Urinary tract obstruction (e.g., kidney stones)

↑πG → ↓GFR

↓ Renal blood flow increased plasma proteins

↓PG → ↓GFR

a) ↑afferent arteriolar resistance (RA )→ ↓PG

↑ Sympathetic activity, (e.g., norepinephrine, endothelin)

b) ↓systemic arterial pressure(AP )→ ↓PG

 Arterial pressure

c) ↓efferent arteriolar resistance (RE )→ ↓PG

↓ Angiotensin II (drugs that block angiotensin II formation)

PG : Glomerular hydrostatic pressure

πB : Colloid osmotic pressure of the proteins in Bowman’s capsule

PB : Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman’s capsule

πG : Colloid osmotic pressure of glomerular capillary plasma proteins

questions.text: The phospholipid that helps in mitochondrial function, and that is found only in the mitochondria is _______
questions.solution:
Cardiolipin is the phospholipid found only in the mitochondria. 

Cardiolipin is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it is essential for the following:

  • Optimal function of numerous mitochondrial enzymes that are involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
  • Maintenance of the structure of the mitochondrial membrane.

Clinical correlate:

Decreased cardiolipin or alteration in its metabolism results in mitochondrial dysfunction seen in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy).

questions.text: Non-sense mutation is seen in _____________.
questions.solution:
Non-sense mutation is seen in β0 thalassemia.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA (i.e., the region of the DNA that  codes for proteins) are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations
  2. Non-sense mutations

1. Missense mutations: These mutations may involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. Because these mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein, they are often referred to as missense mutations.                                                                                                                                                                            Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

a) Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.

b) Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one. An example of this type of mutation is sickle-cell anemia, which is characterized by point mutation affecting the β-globin chain of the hemoglobin, where the nucleotide triplet CTC (or GAG in mRNA), which encodes glutamic acid, is changed to CAC (or GUG in mRNA), which encodes valine.

2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

The illustration below shows various types of point mutations:

Other options:

  • Option b: The α-thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent synthesis of α-globin chains.
  • Option c: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation.
  • Option d: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance suggest pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis Versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolor over the chest.

Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil can be used in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is indicated in the management of hyperthyroidism.

Other options

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin receptor blockers are fetopathic and can cause fetal growth retardation and hypoplasia of organs. 

Statins can cause Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the hanging mark is false?

choices.text: The most common position of the knot is under the chin
The gap in the hanging mark indicates the point of suspension
The hanging mark is situated above the thyroid cartilage
The mark dries to a parchment like consistency post-mortem

questions.solution:
The knot in a suicidal hanging is much less likely to be found under the chin than in other positions - behind the ear or at the occiput.

Hanging mark

  • The hanging mark almost never completely encircles the neck unless a slipknot is used.
  • In most instances the point of suspension is indicated by a gap in the skin mark.
  • This gap is usually seen at one or other side of the neck or at the centre of the back of the neck. Much less often it is under the chin.
  • The hanging mark is situated higher on the neck than in strangulation, usually being directly under the chin anteriorly, passing round beneath the jawbones and rising at the sides or back of the neck to the usual gap under the knot.
  • The mark may be abraded, brown and dried to a parchment-like consistency after death.
  • There may be a narrow red zone either above or below (or both sides) the ligature mark. This is not an indicator of vital reaction but is due to the displacement of blood laterally from under the zone of maximum pressure.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess. 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever. 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis (MG).

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR.

Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
questions.solution:
This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to the Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH).

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the 8th month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: From the following epidemic curve, identify the type of epidemic depicted.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time and they occur within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy.

Types

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is the most universally accepted health status indicator?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic status in which they live.

Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000

It is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care. It is also among the best indicators of state failure.

The best indicator of socio-economic development is the under-5 mortality rate.

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively. 

Hitchhiker thumb deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis. It is seen on the thumb. The deformity has flexion at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint hyperextension at the interphalangeal (IP) joint

 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Subluxation of the 1st MCP joint with hyperextension of the 1st IP joint. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker who is diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the lung presents to the ER with complaints of nausea, confusion,  and dizziness. After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). The SIADH is characterized by:

choices.text: Hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L
Hypernatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L

questions.solution:
The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) is associated with increased urinary excretion of sodium, thereby leading to hyponatremia and urine sodium excretion > 20 mEq/L.

 Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with SIADH due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. 

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH include:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis?
questions.solution:
Ciprofloxacin is used for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts.

  • Antibiotic chemoprophylaxis among close contacts of a patient with invasive meningococcal disease is recommended to prevent secondary cases.
  • Ciprofloxacin is now widely used as a single oral dose, but it cannot be given in pregnancy and those below 18 years of age.
  • In pregnancy and in all ages, ceftriaxone can be given, as a single IM or IV dose. However, reduced susceptibility of isolates to Ceftriaxone has occasionally been reported.

questions.text: The following conditions are commonly associated with Cushing’s syndrome except
questions.solution:
Cushing’s syndrome leads to impaired glucose tolerance and hyperglycemia.

  • Excess mineralocorticoid production may lead to hypertension and hypokalemia
  • Frank psychosis may also be observed in Cushing’s syndrome

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess?
questions.solution:
The blade shown in the image is of the size 11.

The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions

15-blade for minor surgical procedures

questions.text: Most common variant of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is_____
questions.solution:
The most common form of BCC (60%) is the nodular variant, characterized by

  • Pearly opalescent nodules with central depression with umbilication or ulceration and rolled edges and telangiectasia.
  • Seen in sun-exposed areas of individuals over the age of 60.

Other types are:

  • Superficial BCC (15% of BCC) - typically appears on the trunk as a pink or erythematous plaque with a thin pearly border.
  • Infiltrative form
  • Pigmented variant of nodular BCC - difficult to differentiate from nodular melanoma.
  • Morpheaform variant - indistinct borders with a yellow hue.
  • Fibroepithelioma of Pinkus.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is normal peristalsis not seen?
questions.solution:
Achalasia cardia does not show normal peristalsis.

Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows:

  • Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation
  • Aperistalsis of the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure

Diffuse esophageal spasm is characterized by simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of the esophagus. The contractions are spontaneous and may be of abnormally high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration. Intermittent normal peristalsis is seen.

Nutcracker esophagus is characterized by high amplitude (≥180 mmHg) contractions with an increased mean duration. The peristaltic sequence is normal.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter is characterized by elevated LES pressure (≥26 mmHg). Normal peristalsis is seen in the body of the esophagus.

Esophageal carcinoma will not have any issues with the motility or peristalsis.

questions.text: The most common tumor of the parotid gland is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common tumor of the parotid gland is pleomorphic adenoma.

  • 80 to 90% of parotid gland tumors are benign; most commonly, they are pleomorphic adenomas.
  • Most commonly, they arise from the superficial lobe, and all tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.
  • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Slowly growing benign tumor
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Pseudo-capsule present
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumor mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Slowly growing, painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed?
questions.solution:
Endometrial biopsy is the investigation of choice in a case of post-menopausal bleed, as the chances of endometrial cancer are quite high.

For those who undergo TVUS and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation in abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best method to diagnose but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy is the investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.

Puberty in females involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).

Effects of Estrogen:

  • Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips.
  • Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification, and cervical mucus production, induce closure of the epiphyses.
  • Estrogen has a positive effect in maintaining bone formation and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic for check-up following an MTP. On ultrasound, retained tissue was found and the following instrument was used for its removal. What is this instrument?
questions.solution:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.

Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done upto 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only upto 10 weeks of gestation . 

The indications of this procedure are given as follows:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Endometrial aspiration

questions.text: A woman recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an absent Barr body?
questions.solution:
Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome.

Barr body

  • Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus.
  • Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes which become inactivated.
  • The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes.

Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body.

Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body.

Note:

  • Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the other becomes inactive during embryogenesis.
  • Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in neutrophils of females.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the condition given in the picture is posterior dislocation of left hip joint.

The radiograph shows the following findings:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated

questions.text: Flashback phenomenon is more commonly seen with _____.
questions.solution:
Flashback phenomenon is more commonly seen with cannabis.

Flashback phenomenon:

A person experiences sensations related to substance intoxication after the short-term effects of the substance have disappeared. That is person relives the substance(cannabis) use experience without consuming it.

It is also seen in Lysergic acid diethylamide(LSD), phencyclidine which are hallucinogens.

questions.text: Which is the shortest acting muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (succinylcholine) is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant.

It has a rapid-onset (30–60secs) and short duration of action (typically less than 10 min) due to rapid hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase (plasma cholinesterase or pseudocholinesterase).

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing & non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant: 

  • Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant:

Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes)

  • Gantacurium

Short-acting (10-20 minutes)

  • Mivacurium

 Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

  • Atracurium
  • Cisatracurium
  • Vecuronium
  • Rocuronium

Long-acting (>50 minutes)

  • Pancuronium
  • Doxacurium

questions.text: A 15 year old girl comes with itchy lesions on her elbows as shown. Her family history is positive for asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of atopic dermatitis.

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterised by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis or eczema.

A characteristic defect is impaired epidermal barrier. In many patients a mutation in gene encoding filaggrin, a structural protein in the stratum corneum is responsible. The lesions are distributed in the flexural aspects.(as shown in the image).

Patients may display many immunoregulatory abnormalities, including increased IgE synthesis, increased serum IgE levels, delayed type hypersensitivity reactions.

Clinical features:

  • Pruritus and scratching
  • Course marked by exacerbations and remissions
  • Lesions typical of eczematous dermatitis
  • Personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, food allergy, eczema)
  • Clinical course more than 6 weeks
  • Lichenification of skin

questions.text: Identify the MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T2 weighted image as the CSF appears bright/hyperintense and white matter appears dark. 

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, of which the most classic are T1 and T2 weighted images.

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. As a result, CSF is dark. However, white matter is dark and grey matter is bright similar to T2 imaging.

STIR (short tau inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fat from T2. So, fat is dark. It is done to detect bone marrow edema in body part scans.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

Structure
T1 image
T2 image
Grey matter
Darker
 Lighter
White matter
 Lighter  Darker
CSF/ Fluids
Dark
Bright
Fat
White
Less white
Air
Dark
Dark
Cortical bone
Dark
Dark
Tendons and ligaments
Dark
Dark
Calcification
Dark
Dark
Flowing blood and hemosiderin
Dark
Dark

questions.text: PET stands for:
questions.solution:
PET stands for positron emission tomography.

  • Positron emission tomography (PET) is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that produces a three – dimensional image or picture of functional processes in the body. Three – dimensional images of tracer concentration within the body are then constructed by computer analysis.
  • Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) and Positron emission tomography (PET) are nuclear medicine imaging techniques which provide metabolic and functional information, unlike CT and MRI.

Positron emission tomography (PET)

Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT)

Very expensive

Uses positron emitting radioisotope (tracer) - 18F-FDG

 

 

 

Better contrast and spatial resolution

 

Lower cost

Uses gamma emitting radioisotope (tracer)

Technetium-99 m

Iodine-123

Iodine-131

Less contrast and spatial resolution
